retirement.title: Retirement Planning
retirement.description: Key terms for retirement savings, income planning, and benefit strategies

terms.definition: An employer-sponsored retirement savings plan that allows employees to contribute pre-tax dollars, reducing current taxable income. Many employers offer matching contributions up to a certain percentage.
A tax-advantaged savings account for retirement. Traditional IRAs offer tax-deductible contributions with taxable withdrawals, while Roth IRAs use after-tax contributions with tax-free withdrawals.

A retirement account funded with after-tax dollars where qualified withdrawals in retirement are completely tax-free, including all investment gains. Subject to income limits for direct contributions.
The minimum amount you must withdraw annually from tax-deferred retirement accounts starting at age 73. Failure to take RMDs results in a 25% penalty on the amount not withdrawn.
A federal insurance program providing retirement income, disability benefits, and survivor benefits funded through payroll taxes. Benefits are based on your 35 highest-earning years.
A retirement plan where an employer guarantees a specific monthly benefit in retirement based on salary history and years of service. Also known as a defined benefit plan.
A retirement plan that promises a predetermined monthly benefit at retirement, typically calculated using a formula based on salary and years of service. The employer bears the investment risk.
A retirement plan where the employee and/or employer contribute a defined amount, but the final benefit depends on investment performance. Examples include 401(k) and 403(b) plans.

An insurance contract that provides guaranteed income payments for a specified period or for life. Can be immediate (payments start now) or deferred (payments start later). Used to create predictable retirement income.
An annual increase to Social Security and some pension benefits designed to keep pace with inflation, typically based on the Consumer Price Index (CPI).

insurance.title: Insurance & Protection
insurance.description: Life insurance, disability, and asset protection terminology

terms.definition: A permanent life insurance policy where the cash value growth is linked to a stock market index (like the S&P 500) with a guaranteed floor protecting against losses. Combines death benefit protection with tax-advantaged cash value accumulation.

Life insurance that provides coverage for a specific period (10, 20, or 30 years). If the insured dies during the term, beneficiaries receive the death benefit. Generally the most affordable type of life insurance.
Permanent life insurance with guaranteed level premiums, a guaranteed death benefit, and a guaranteed cash value that grows at a fixed rate. Provides lifelong coverage as long as premiums are paid.
The savings component of a permanent life insurance policy that grows tax-deferred over time. Can be accessed through policy loans or withdrawals for supplemental retirement income or emergencies.
The amount paid to beneficiaries upon the death of the insured person. Generally received income-tax-free by beneficiaries and can be used for any purpose.
Life insurance riders that allow the policyholder to access a portion of the death benefit while still alive if diagnosed with a terminal, chronic, or critical illness.
Insurance that covers the cost of extended care services not covered by health insurance or Medicare, including nursing home care, assisted living, and in-home care.
Insurance that replaces a portion of your income if you become unable to work due to illness or injury. Can be short-term (up to 2 years) or long-term (to age 65+).
The regular payment made to an insurance company to maintain coverage. Premiums vary based on age, health, coverage amount, and policy type.
The process by which an insurance company evaluates the risk of insuring an applicant, determining eligibility and premium rates based on health, lifestyle, and other factors.

tax.title: Tax Strategy
tax.description: Tax planning, optimization, and regulatory terminology

terms.definition: An investment arrangement where taxes on earnings are postponed until funds are withdrawn, typically in retirement. Examples include traditional IRAs, 401(k)s, and annuities.
Income or investment gains that are permanently free from federal income tax. Roth IRA qualified withdrawals and municipal bond interest are common examples.
Selling investments at a loss to offset capital gains and reduce taxable income. Up to $3,000 in net losses can be deducted against ordinary income annually, with excess losses carried forward.
Tax on profit from selling an asset for more than its purchase price. Long-term gains (held over 1 year) are taxed at preferential rates of 0%, 15%, or 20% depending on income.
The tax rate applied to the last dollar of income earned. The U.S. uses a progressive system with brackets ranging from 10% to 37%, where only income within each bracket is taxed at that rate.
A tax on the transfer of wealth at death. In 2026, estates exceeding the exemption amount (currently ~$13.6 million per individual) are taxed at rates up to 40%.
A tax on transferring assets to another person during your lifetime without receiving full value in return. Annual exclusion allows gifts up to $18,000 per recipient without tax consequences.
A tax-deferral strategy allowing investors to sell an investment property and reinvest proceeds into a similar property while deferring capital gains taxes. Strict timelines and rules apply.
Dividends from domestic and qualifying foreign corporations that meet specific holding period requirements and are taxed at the lower long-term capital gains rates rather than ordinary income rates.
A parallel tax system designed to ensure high-income taxpayers pay a minimum amount of tax by limiting certain deductions and exclusions. Calculated separately from regular income tax.

investment.title: Investment Terms
investment.description: Core investment concepts and portfolio management terminology

terms.definition: The process of dividing investments among different asset classes (stocks, bonds, cash, real estate) based on your goals, risk tolerance, and time horizon to optimize returns while managing risk.
Spreading investments across various asset classes, sectors, and geographies to reduce risk. The principle that a diversified portfolio tends to have less volatile returns than any single investment.

An investment strategy of regularly investing a fixed dollar amount regardless of market conditions. This approach reduces the impact of volatility by buying more shares when prices are low and fewer when high.
A legal obligation to act in the best interest of a client. Fiduciary advisors must put their clients' interests ahead of their own and disclose any conflicts of interest.
A mutual fund or ETF designed to track the performance of a specific market index, such as the S&P 500. Offers broad market exposure with low fees and is a cornerstone of passive investing.
Interest earned on both the initial principal and previously accumulated interest. Often called the 'eighth wonder of the world,' compounding accelerates wealth growth over long time horizons.

The degree of variability in investment returns that an individual is willing to withstand. Influenced by factors including age, income, financial goals, and personal comfort with market fluctuations.
The process of realigning the weightings of portfolio assets back to target allocations. Involves periodically buying or selling assets to maintain the desired level of asset allocation and risk.
The income return on an investment, expressed as a percentage of the investment's cost or current market value. Includes dividends from stocks and interest from bonds.
The ease with which an asset can be converted to cash without significantly affecting its price. Cash is the most liquid asset, while real estate and certain investments are less liquid.

estate.title: Estate Planning
estate.description: Wealth transfer, trusts, and legacy planning terminology

terms.definition: A legal arrangement where a trustee holds and manages assets on behalf of beneficiaries according to terms set by the grantor. Trusts can avoid probate, reduce estate taxes, and protect assets.
A legal document that specifies how a person's assets should be distributed after death, names guardians for minor children, and designates an executor to manage the estate.
A person or entity designated to receive assets from an insurance policy, retirement account, trust, or estate. Beneficiary designations typically override instructions in a will.
A legal document authorizing someone to act on your behalf for financial or healthcare decisions if you become incapacitated. A 'durable' POA remains in effect during incapacity.
The legal process of validating a will and distributing a deceased person's assets under court supervision. Can be time-consuming and expensive, which is why many people use trusts to avoid it.
A trust that generally cannot be modified or terminated after creation without the beneficiaries' consent. Assets placed in an irrevocable trust are removed from the grantor's taxable estate.
A trust that can be modified or dissolved by the grantor during their lifetime. Primarily used to avoid probate and provide seamless management of assets if the grantor becomes incapacitated.
A collection of legal documents and strategies for managing and distributing assets during life and after death. Typically includes a will or trust, powers of attorney, and healthcare directives.
The person or institution named to take over management of a trust when the original trustee can no longer serve, either due to incapacity or death.

An irrevocable trust that provides income to the donor or beneficiaries for a specified period, with the remaining assets going to a designated charity. Offers income tax deductions and estate tax benefits.

general.title: General Finance
general.description: Foundational financial concepts and personal finance terminology

terms.definition: The total value of all assets minus all liabilities. A key measure of financial health that includes property, investments, cash, and retirement accounts minus debts like mortgages and loans.
The total amount of money coming in (income) minus money going out (expenses) over a specific period. Positive cash flow enables saving, investing, and building wealth over time.
A readily accessible savings reserve, typically 3-6 months of living expenses, set aside for unexpected financial needs such as job loss, medical emergencies, or major repairs.
A personal finance metric calculated by dividing total monthly debt payments by gross monthly income. Lenders use DTI to assess borrowing capacity; generally, a DTI below 36% is considered healthy.
A three-digit number (300-850) representing creditworthiness, calculated from payment history, credit utilization, length of credit history, credit mix, and new credit inquiries.
The rate at which the general level of prices for goods and services rises over time, eroding purchasing power. A critical factor in retirement planning, as it reduces the real value of savings.

terms.full_name: Annual Percentage Rate / Annual Percentage Yield
terms.definition: APR is the annual cost of borrowing without compounding. APY is the annual return on savings including compound interest. APY is always equal to or higher than APR due to compounding effects.

The process of spreading loan payments over time in regular installments. Early payments are mostly interest, while later payments apply more to principalâ€”a concept important for mortgages and large loans.
The difference between an asset's market value and the outstanding balance of any loans against it. In homeownership, equity builds as mortgage principal is paid down and/or property value increases.

An economic concept measuring the monetary value of an individual's future earning potential, used to determine appropriate life insurance coverage. Factors include age, income, benefits, and expenses.
